name: Book of Invasions

attributes.attribute: attempts to bring Ireland’s history into Judeo-Christian tradition
useful tool for discovering Ireland’s past
significant resource for study of Irish mythology

sources: Cross, Tom Peete, and Clark Harris Slover, eds. *Ancient Irish Tales*. (New York: Henry Holt and Co., 1936).
MacAlister, R. A. Stewart. *Lebor Gabála Érenn: The Book of the Taking of Ireland, Parts 1–4.* Dublin: Irish Texts Society, 1941.
MacAlister, R. A. Stewart. Lebor Gabála Érenn: The Book of the Taking of Ireland, Part 5. Dublin: Irish Texts Society, 1956.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: Lebor Gabála Érenn or the Book of Invasions is a literary text, which means "the book of the takings of Ireland" or "the book of Irish conquests" in Irish language. While it was compiled in the 12th century through many manuscripts, certain parts of the text date back to much earlier times. This poetic text recounts the six invasions of Ireland, beginning from the era of the biblical flood to the arrival of the ultimate settlers. Despite some interruptions of biblical material in the text, it is an indispensable resource for those studying Celtic mythology. The invasions are recounted in order, starting with Cesair, granddaughter of Noah, who escaped the biblical flood in her ark, but whose line didn't survive long. After her came the Partholonians, descendants of the Giant Magog, who arrived from the east but were wiped out by a plague. Lastly, the Nemedians followed their leader Nemed, people from the Caspian Sea who fought the monstrous Fomorian people. As the story progresses, the Fomorians appear repeatedly and are beaten back time and again by new arrivals, albeit never invading Ireland. They consistently establish themselves on the island, suggesting that they are native inhabitants. The Nemedians were forced to leave Ireland after being driven out by the Fomorians, and endured centuries of enslavement until they returned to the island under the new name of Fir Bolg. The text doesn't mention the Fomorians at this point, indicating that either they didn't pose a threat to the Fir Bolg or that the two groups made an alliance. The Tuatha Dé Danann, known as the people of the goddess Danu, proved to be dominant over the Fir Bolg and surviving Fomorians when the ultimate immortal race arrived in Ireland. They ruled over Ireland for multiple centuries. Nevertheless, the immortals were limited by time and had to relinquish their power to the Milesians, a mortal race consisting of the descendants and followers of a Scythian man who wedded an Irishwoman of nobility. Even though they defeated the Tuatha Dé, their rivals did not abandon the country; they vanished below ground and became the Fairy people. The Book of Invasions, written after the Christianization era, aims to incorporate Ireland's history into the Judeo-Christian tradition, incorporating stories such as that of Noah. Despite these inclusions, scholars utilize the book's blend of facts and myths, and established connections between Ireland's past migrations and archeological proof, making it a valuable research tool for the study of Irish mythology and the history of Ireland.
